>Organs don't have pain receptors
This is true, which is why if you have a stomach ache or other gut issues you will feel pain but its more general.

If you have a cut on your hand or a bruise or scrape or whatever, you can easily pinpoint the injury by pain, but with organs its more vague.

A heart attack will cause pain in your left (or right?) arm. Gut issues can cause pain in your entire abdomen. Kidney issues feel like back pain.

Your body KNOWS something is wrong and sends you messages (pain) about it, but with your guts your body can't pin it down as well so it just fucks up the entire area. lol

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28285851
The reason you are lonely and miserable is entirely due to your own choices. It doesn't matter if life is an uphill battle for you, it doesn't matter that you struggle with things that come naturally to other people. At the end of the day, you either climb that hill, or you don't. And you're sitting at its base, being full of agony and self-pity, resenting those that make it up the hill. Your misery is of your own design.
You could spend your time gazing inwards. Instead of lamenting that others have it easier, you could try to find out why you have it harder. But you won't do that by sitting at the foot of the hill and moping, you'll do it trying to climb. If you fail, and you will do so countless times, you have to calmly and objectively observe why you failed and find ways to counter it. The guy furthest up the hill just climbs, because it's in his nature. The guy at the midway point struggles, because it is *not* in his nature, but nonetheless he climbs. He doesn't compare himself to the guy on the top of the hill, but he does compare himself to himself before he found a way this far up. That guy also doesn't beat himself up for his physical ineptitude. He realises he can't change the fact that life didn't give him a climber's disposition. He also realises that he can still climb. It's tough for him, but succeeding after a lot of trial and error gives him satisfaction. Do you know why it does? Because he embraced the uncertainty of not knowing whether he can succeed, time and again, after every failure, and tried anyway.
You know what he didn't do? Sit at the foot of the hill and feel sorry for himself because he's not a natural born climber.

I'm in a similar boat, OP. Probably less extreme, but I feel similarly.
Did whatever you do just happen? Time will pass and the intensity of your shame will, too. Eventually it will no longer be in the forefront of your mind, and will only come back and haunt you on occasion.

We can't define ourselves as the sum of our past mistakes.
Use this as an opportunity to steer yourself in the right direction.

The first thing you need to do is practice some self care. Even if you think it's pointless.

Get some new clothes. They don't have to be high fashion, just something clean and neat and average.

Eat more and/or work out to build up your frame. You don't need fancy gym equipment, a simple pullup bar that fits into a doorframe is an amazingly flexible and cheap tool for this. The rush of endorphins you'll get from using it will help a bunch as well.

Assuming you actually are ugly (you're probably overstating this because of your mental state), that can often be compensated for somewhat with well-suited hairstyles and good skin care.

Knowledge in itself doesn't signify intelligence. You can catch up on the knowledge you've missed out on with diligent study, and that includes the social skills you've let slip.

I'm sorry.

From what you've written it's possible that you were in an abusive relationship, but it's hard to say. You may want to watch this video about the narcissistic discard cycle to see if any of it rings true:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iMch0y85Kj8

When relationships come to an end it's a messy situation and the extreme sides of each person's personality comes out. Which means it's possible that he was expressing transient narcissism, and not the full spectrum of it. The projection tactic, which he employed to shift all the blame onto you, is one of the traits that narcissists employ during the discard cycle. And that's why I'm bringing it up, so you can research it for yourself. If it turns out that you were in an abusive relationship, that knowledge may provide a closure to the relationship which you never would have received otherwise.

The best thing you can do now is go no contact for your sake, and stick with it. The person that loved you is no longer your ally, they no longer have your back. 7 years is a long time to be in a relationship, it'll take awhile to heal from this. I wouldn't rush the healing process or rush into a new relationship. I tried to get into a new relationship with a woman a year after my breakup and it was out of the frying pan and into the fire for me. Suffice it to say, it was a big mistake.

You're not wrong for trying to salvage the relationship or to try to get through to him with your words. From his perspective you were manipulating him but what you were doing was everything you could to keep the relationship together. Don't let him beat you up over it and don't beat yourself up over it. To have just walked away without a fight means you didn't love him. That you humiliated yourself to try to salvage it speaks volumes. You did all you could.

There isn't much more I can say. But if you want to talk about anything else I'll be around in another 8-10 hours from now to reply.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I went through something similar 4 years ago. It still affects me today. This isn't advice, just my own experience. This past year saw more recovery than the first 3 combined because I realized something:

The version of him you fell in love with isn't who he is today. The guy in your memories doesn't exist any more. He's changed and mentally went through what you are now long before the break up. He was in the moving on phase when things ended. You're already a few months behind from day 1. Things will never be the same, and he doesn't want them to be. You don't matter to him anymore, but you already do and will to someone better.

Take time to grieve. Then reflect and grow. Don't throw a pity party for yourself for too long. I wasted years doing that in hopes she'd see and try to reconnect out of guilt or something.

What you liked and didn't like about the relationship- use that to shape your life. It's much easier to find make decisions when you've clearly defined what you're wanting. Take what you liked and didn't like about him personally and list a few uncompromisable must-haves and deal-breakers for future relationships at all levels. Reflect on what he didn't like about you and give it a fair examination. Fix your bad habits and whatever valid complaints about you that you wouldn't want your partner to have. Hold yourself to your own standards.

It takes time but it's worth it in the end. You start attracting higher quality people at all level of relationships- basic friends, professional, romantic, and everything in between. Deeper connections and true friends. The hardest part is simply beginning and allowing yourself to go at your own pace.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28290764
>>28290624
These two. I want to stress how important the Gym part is, too. Your mind isn't a separate, detached entity from your body, it's literally the most important part of it. Your neurochemistry is greatly influenced by what your body does, and exercise releases endorphines and dopamine which give you drive and a feeling of being content/accomplished. Depending on how severe your condition is you might have to stick with it, and it's not a cure-all because you can't lift negative life decisions away. But it'll make it easer and give you a better baseline to work with.

posts.com: Amping up your mental issue as some impending doom will only make things worse. You are worth feeling good about. You are worth feeling happy and in control. This is just a setback.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28290400
you're not screwed up, thinking that there's something broken about you will only make you more miserable and unwilling to take action, which is the best way out of those feelings.
As someone who dropped out of uni and struggles to find a job while not having friends or a girlfriend i truly understand what you feel.
So one way to snap out of it was to stop looking at it like some giant monolith of a problem that can't be solved but i started breaking things down so that the baby steps that i were taking felt meaningful in some way.
"Too fucking miserable to get out and meet someone" ...well, can you at least go get some groceries?
"To fucking miserable to even get out of bed"... okay, can you move your legs at least? Start moving until you are able to get up.
It sounds silly but break things down to the most basic level to a point where you are capable of overcoming them.
Also get a skill of some kind, doesn't have to be job related, although it's better if it is. But once you managed to get rid of that feeling this should be the next goal. To find something that's so meaningful to you that you feel is even more important than your life.
Also this >>28290409. No matter what tragedy will come in the future, nothing can take away your right to feel happy and love yourself right now.

posts.sub: Taking advice from 4chan is idiotic
posts.com:
Nobody here knows you or your specific circumstances. Even if you take the time to fully flesh these out when you post, (which would be an extraordinarily rare occurrence) it is unlikely that you will succeed. From this it follows that advice givers have not the knowledge or context necessary to give useful advice. Advice givers are scarcely, if ever, qualified to give even remotely reasonable answers to your queries. They could be teenagers lacking in experience, or extremely idiotic people.
Even if this lack of in depth knowledge into your case could be somehow solved, 4chan posters do not have your best interests at heart. Some do, but they are in the minority. Many people here are hedonists who will advise you to take the path of most pleasure as opposed to the righteous path. This, of course, will lead to certain dissatisfaction and confusion in due time. Other posters will intentionally mislead you, as they believe it to be funny.
4chan is not the real world. 4chan does not reflect the real world. To know the world, you must live in it. That implies leaving your computer and going out into it.
Go out, live, acquire experience, and learn from it. Analyze your mistakes and strive to avoid them in the future. Reinforce good habits and purge bad ones. Humans learn by doing, as opposed to reading inane, ill-intentioned advice on internet forums.

posts.name: Anonymous

If you must ask advice, seek people around you that care about your well-being and are cognizant of the circumstances that you find yourself in, or who will more readily understand them once you explain. Parents, grandparents, siblings, friends, teachers are all good examples.
While some things of value can be gleaned from 4chan, they are of sporadic ocurrence. Attempting to find them is akin to looking for a needle in a garbage pile. The more you browse and post here, the more you will become like the people here, which is not what you want. Go out into the world and be a shining beacon for others. Be a woman or man of good.

posts.sub: I dont even know what companies want?
posts.com:
Everytime I scroll the page at indeed.com I see listings with crazy specific qualifications. On some they need very specfic experiece installing shelves with a certain finish and wont take anyone else, other times they want managers with experience with very specific systems no one could possibly have in depth knowledge in, and in others they ask extremely bizarre qualifications on top of everything else...

I know I dont have the necessary experience for these jobs, but seeing these weird requirements confuses me. How on earth am I gonna get that sort of very specific knowledge, even with education? I see a ton of job listings asking for logistics knowledge, and while I dont have it, I could get a low level wagie job coordinating entry and stock supply at the local walmart, and in my mind 6 months of that would be enough. But I can also tell I'd waste a lot of otherwise valuable time on useless experience, since they would probably be using completely different systems and would want a certain type of worker profile. I also see office clerk positions that need experience managing inventories, and I imagine getting into a warehouse would be a good start, but they then ask for 5+ years using a very niche excel-like software have a hard time googling online, and would deffinitely not be experienced in, even if I was the lead warehouse manager.

How on earth do I get good versatile experience? is choosing a career a gamble? I'd have no way of landing a job if I had finished college. Even with a diploma and some experience in some place, I wouldnt really have what employers are specifically looking for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For example, a while ago I started studying japanese to improve my job prospects. I had lessons in highschool, so I felt like I had a leg up in the language, and just needed a year or two to get it down to conversation level. When I realized how autistic japanese people are about small details, I started to reconsider why I was doing this, so I took a look around the jobs people were offering for japanese translators, since I heard it was a very well sought after skill to have.

I found out most jobs in my area that needed japanese also asked for a bachelor's degree in administration, 5+ years in a certain system doing idk why, another bachelor's degree in finance/a STEM degree, and having lived in Japan for 5+ years. I had to have an entire list of qualifications to even be considered, and many other offers were like this as well. It wasnt a nice skill to have, but part of a laundry list of weird qualifications I could never have. If I had kept studying japanese as hard as I was, and gone to college for my stem degree, I would NOT be using whatever extra niche skills I developed, because it was a complete shot in the dark that at the time had a solid chance, and by the time I would have learnt the language, there wouldnt be any jobs seeking for a jap speaking degree haver. Maybe I would have gotten a job, but it would most deffinitely not be worth the years I would have invested in learning those skills.

How on earth can you know what will be useful experience in the future? I have some experience, but no one has given me a job for my skills, despite being very transferrable to the jobs I applied to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Why do they put up some job posting for someone incredibly specific?
Because they know the corporation next door just fired 10 of those people to move the factory to China. And all those 10 people are competing with you for a job they have spent 25 years doing. So of course you can't compete with them.

The key is that you need to get a job first, any job, to BE one of those people. And gain those skills.

This is why many college grads focus hard on careers that you can enter with just degrees and internships (like programming). If you don't want one of those, you need to know people in the industry and network with them until one of them gives you a chance.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28290213
Seconding.
What works for me is to just be upfront. Not about having autism, but about what I need when someone communicates with me. I'll stick to those that make an effort to accommodate that, and make efforts to accommodate them in turn. The others I don't bother with, I have neither the time nor the energy to memorize the entire road map of non verbal cues and what they actually mean by implicit statements. It's left me with few but good friends that I hang out with every now and then.
What sets me back far more than my ASD is my ADHD, I tend to just forget people exist for prolonged periods of time and don't reach out much (partially due to past experiences).
As for your girlfriend problem, try getting on multiple dating apps at once and be patient. My girlfriend is also ASD/ADHD and we found each other on OKC. It took me two years of repeated rejection and failed first date but when I met her we really clicked despite the first date being really awkward. Do looksmax, physical appearance is a part of attraction after all. But the key is to be patient. Dating sucks and will often feel like a waste of time, but it beats being alone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28289413
>>28289610
You're onto something here.
Although explaining it to you is not the best way to convey it. But you know what? I'm feeling wordy today, so fuck it.

These corporations are selling you a false bag of goods.
They say 'just do it' but then provide you with an image of someone considered to be arguably the best at what they do.
But 'Doing' does not equate success even though it's sold that way.
Before there can be resolution you must separate the image from the problem otherwise understanding will evade you.

As far as overthinking being the biggest problem:
It's not really a problem until you try to solve it and we as human beings can't help but to solve problems.
People love to make a name for themselves as the problem solver so you'll see quotes like the one you posted a lot.
But overthinking is not a problem; it's a process which we need to go through as a species.

So let's get to the meat of it:
You overthink and you fail due to inaction, you stop overthinking and you fail because you didn't think it through.
No matter which way you go you lose. These types of no-win situations can drive a human being mad, especially if they can't bow out of the game or petition to the game-master that the game is unfair.

But is this really a no-win situation?
It is so long as you play by the rules that you need to be all one way or the other.

As human beings we tend to overthink more than we act. We plan instead of act, we choose instead of deciding, we vacillate with anxiety instead of moving with conviction. A middle way exists, a way of least resistance, the watercourse way — whatever you want to call it — exists between both planning and action, choice and decision and anxiety and conviction. To do away with one or the other is missing the point entirely.

The point is to flow like the water which you are; and to contemplate in stillness like the various minerals and proteins which comprise your organism.
That's it, it's that simple.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Rather than overthinking inside your head, you should be continually observing, because by doing so you are picking up cues and learning from other people's life experiences. The goal is for decisions to be made subconsciously in real time, based on acquired knowledge and experience. Whereas trying to brainstorm all the pros and cons and probabilities of various outcomes for every possible course of action only paralyzes your brain with indecision in the moment of action. But one shouldn't automatically blame failure on "overthinking" or "not thinking enough". Someone T-boned at a green light had no way to out-think or dodge the 50 mph red light runner. Making a major purchase without thinking it through could lead to massive regret. But trying to use the same pros-cons-probs approach for matters of the heart is bound to sow doubt and anxiety while solving nothing. Any success or failure you experience in romance is due to feelings one has no conscious control over. Analysis is only wallowing in the pain of failure.

My friend, they're boiling it down to a snappy slogan but there is truth in it. "Overthinking" by definition, means you're doing too much of it, i.e. to an unhealthy degree. It's good to think about things, it's good to think things through, but there comes a point where you need to take action.

Ignore what these idiots are saying, they're just brands, who cares. But yes, if you never do anything and just spend all your time thinking about what you could do, you'll never get anything done. Think about all the things you're best at in the world, how many of them did you give endless thought to before doing them? How many of them did you just get on and start fucking doing it? You don't have to not think while you're doing it too, keep thinking to see if you can do better now that you understand what you're doing more.
So yes, literally just start doing something. If you can't, instead of spending your time overthinking other shit, start thinking about why you can't do something and then fix it.

Ok, Harvard alum here.
First off, STOP vomiting your life story online. It will do you no good, and will be used 90% of the time in a nonproductive fashion. These are not your friends, they are bored people who mean you harm for entertainment purposes.
Right now you are a monkey dancing to their music for coins, and you should rethink continuing to engage.

Getting into Harvard is a big deal, admittedly. But capitalizing on your opportunities while there and graduating is far more challenging.
I grew up in Boston, and was working as a commercial fisherman before and during my time at Harvard. Socially I struggled until I started treating undergrad like a job. I tolerated my peers, and as you know, they require you to live in the dorms your first 2 years, or tgey used to at least, so you will have opportunity to make friends and acquaintences.
You now have the opportunity to make opportunities FOR YOURSELF, and this negates the points of criticism you received- you will have to be self-made from here on out, rising or falling on merit alone.
You can't win the oppression olympics. It is not a real thing and every entrant is a judge and already judged themselves as the winner.
You know the best way to win a zero-sum game is never to play.

Final thought: I go to the Harvard Club of the Palm Beaches pretty regularly. I do a lot of networking there and the food is excellent. As an adult I enjoy my time there more than I did in the dorms. Since I went just a 20 minute walk down the street for grad school at MIT, which also grants membership in the Club, I tend towards the tech side. With the mellowing of age and without the pressure-cooker environment, socially, having gone has been VERY good to me.
Paying for it was a cast-iron bitch at first, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28286338
if you are making minimum wage, there won't be much, so just bank it for now.

Once you get like $1000 in savings and see how easy it is to save (or how hard) then you can start buying CDs. CDs were a shit investment for like 20+ years but are good now.

Like if you can save $1000 in 3 months, then take $500 and buy a CD for about a year duration. You won't be able to touch the money, but you should be able to get 4% or so on it.

three months later, you can do it again, so you build a "ladder" of cds that will start coming due every three months. You can decide then what to do with the money at that time.

This is good because CDs lock up your money so you can't spend it for the duration of the term. This also will get you in the practice of saving regularly.

This is the best you can do right now.

CD = Certificate of Deposit
Basically a savings certificate where you give them a certain amount of money for a pre-determined period of time and get a higher interest rate in return.

Like if you put $5,000 euros in at 4% for one year, you would have $5,200 euros at the end of the year, but couldn't use the money in the meantime.

I dont know enough about european housing/etc to be much help.

Infection – the most common include posthitis and balanitis. Posthitis is infection of the foreskin, usually caused by fungus thriving in the hot and moist conditions. Balanitis is infection of the foreskin and glans, and is usually caused by poor hygiene. Smegma encourages the growth of infection-causing germs.
Chronic infections – for some males, posthitis or balanitis tends to recur. A complication of chronic infections is scar tissue, which could stick the foreskin to the glans and make retraction impossible. Chronic infections of the penis and foreskin also increase the risk of urinary tract infections. Repeated kidney infections can affect kidney function.
Phimosis – the foreskin is abnormally tight, which prevents it from retracting. This can cause recurrent balanitis because good hygiene is difficult or impossible. An erection may cause the foreskin to split and bleed. The tight foreskin can also hinder urination – in some cases, the foreskin fills up with urine like a little balloon. Phimosis is the most common reason for circumcision after infancy.
Paraphimosis – permanently retracted foreskin. The foreskin gathers like a tight rubber band around the penis, causing swelling and pain. This condition is the second most common reason for adult circumcision.
Tumour – rarely, abnormal growths develop on the foreskin. In some cases, the tumour is cancerous. Penile cancer is extremely rare in circumcised men.
Zipper trauma – the foreskin (or other parts of the genitals, commonly the scrotum) gets caught in a zipper. Wearing underpants is the best prevention.

Its a janitorial job. I've worked them before. I was a part-time office monkey who worked 25 hours a week and who got offered extra pay to work as a night janitor because one of our two janitors were leaving. All I can tell you is my experience.

I came in after the regular employees left. I was trusted with security codes. I sweated over getting it right. Then came the actual job itself. I was a thorough custodian. I cleaned everything well. Yada yada, you can imagine cleaning on your job, I know thorough cleaning on mine.

You're going to learn something about women's bathrooms. They're nasty. Genuinely nasty. As the custodian it's literally your problem. Before I did that job I thought that the women's bathroom would be nice and clean after seeing many men's bathrooms. It was not. Turns out bitches are nasty.

You get past unclogging toilets and sinks with blood and tampons in them. So the job itself. It's spooky. You're basically alone in a building. You find out that there are weird noises. Some are from outside of the building, some are from inside of the building. Shit makes noises that you would never expect. You learn a lot about what the building is like when it's dead silent and you're the only one there. It's pretty spooky. Sometimes you're in the building and somebody pulls up in the middle of the night in the parking lot and just sits there. And you're hearing noises inside of the building.

It's... it's like 50% mindgames to be a custodial worker like that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28290542
Well, what is it that you are fundamentally afraid of in this situation? Are you worried about rejection? Worried about getting hurt? These have different remedies.

Worrying about getting rejected is generally about low self-esteem - you have to try and find a way to feel better about yourself, and value yourself enough that it becomes believable that other people might value you too. It also helps, paradoxically, to go on some really disastrous first dates; when you've done that, you realise that life actually goes on: you were single then; you're single now; life hasn't actually got any worse. So did the rejection matter? Not really. Once you get that, it ceases to be something to be scared of and just becomes irritating.

If you're worried about getting hurt, that's trickier, because break-ups really do hurt. What I think you need to do there is to consider the alternative: if you're never with anyone, you can't be hurt; but it's also awfully lonely, and you're denying yourself the chance of being happy. The risk of being hurt is one that everyone takes getting involved with someone; but it's a risk that most people think is worth taking. I've had my heart broken - more than once, in fact - but I still took the chance of getting involved with my current bf, and I am very happy indeed that I did.

>Counter: They just should not associate with anyone who I would have reason to be suspicious of
First, your suspicions are the product of irrational and absurd paranoia. In the real world (outside the insane alt-right echo chamber) vast numbers of men and women are purely platonic friends.

Second, if you take this attitude, you're acting like a woman doesn't have agency; as if cheating is something that just happens to her and is completely outside her conscious control.

Now, perhaps this actually is the case with you. Maybe you are so completely controlled by your testicles that if a woman is attracted to you, you are physically incapable of *not* having sex with her. If that's the case, I can see why you might imagine that women are the same way, by simple projection.

But in fact they aren't. If a woman is not attracted to a man, it doesn't matter if he's attracted to her - she's not going to fuck him. It doesn't matter if you are suspicious of him - *she* is not going to fuck him.

Even more importantly, even if she actually *is* attracted to another man, she can still choose not to fuck him. People (normal, sane people, that if y) choose not to have sex all the time. So long as her relationship with you is actually valuable to her, so long as she loves you, she won't *want* to cheat on you. She won't want to damage what you and she have. Even in a case where there is actually some physical attraction, she still won't *want* to cheat. And so she won't.

But as soon as you start acting like a jealous, controlling asshole, at that point, her loyalty to you will evaporate. At the point, what you and she have will no longer be valuable enough to her that she won't want to risk damaging it. At that point, if she's attracted to another guy she *will* cheat, because you acting like an asshole has made her want to.

>>28288994
>Psychology
Ah, fellow Psychbro! Welp, if you only have a bachelor's, then you're SOL in terms of job opportunities since you'll pretty much only have the ability to get substance abuse therapy jobs with your degree (unless you're able to fanangle your way into a job and seriously salespitch your degree up like a business mogul). My recommendation is to try and get accepted into a university that has a masters-phd track where you can do either clinical or experimental psychology. If you don't have lab/research experience and/or your gpa's not the best, then you're gonna be in for a rough time (you'll need to have both to have a decent chance, so it may make sense to hit up your old professors for guidance and to gain experience). You can either go the PHD for psychology route which branches out to either clinical or experimental psychology, or you can get a masters in social work which may be more forgiving in terms of requirements.
If neither of those options sound good to you, then do what I'm doing and go to medical school. Depending on the classes you took, you may have to go back and get a year of physics, year of chemistry and year of organic chemistry under your belt to satisfy the course pre-requisites that most medical schools have. You'll, of course, have to prepare for and take the MCAT, get shadowing hours in and volunteer to make yourself the best candidate you can. Note that this option is likely the path of most resistance as it's going to take a fair amount of time, but will it ultimately matter in the end when you become a psychiatrist and make 300-400k a year?
Legitimately feel for you, Psychbro, it isn't easy going for this degree since the only option is to continue education lest it rot on the side.

>>28283855
How did the fight start? In my experience, some dogs, especially the energetic breeds (such as lab), like to chase smaller things (cats). You are gonna need to train your dog not to, and re-integrate them slowly. Dogs respond to food motivation, and negative feelings (NOT hitting them, but like spray bottles, only hit if your dog bites and won't let go). How often do you play with your dog, and walk him? Sometimes dogs can have emotional reasons for lashing out (anxiety, among other things), and there is medication that will help with that, if exercising your dog doesn't work.

Take your dog to a trainer.

posts.com:
>>28287319
Get into the trades. You can get set up with the unions, and they'll pay you while you're an apprentice, and later when you're out there fully commuting to the job. The Electrician's Union is a good place to go, so is the plumbers/pipefitter's union, as well as the Trucking Industry(no unions needed for that one, just your CDL). You could also get into the Carpenter's Union, or the Laborers Union, or you could get into the painting business, which is big money, especially for a young guy like yourself. You could also get into window cleaning, or pressure Washing or you could mow lawns, or Weld/boilermaking. You could get into HVACR, which is where you fix air conditioners, heaters, and refrigerators, there's good money in that. You could also get into automotive repair, or even truck repair. You could make a killing doing one of those. Or you could be an airplane mechanic, or you could maintenance machines, that's a steady job worth looking into.

Have fun with hobbies on the side, you need to make some money that lasts, and you can do that. I just listed a bunch of options for you, go out and check your local options. You could also get into roofing. You'd need some sunscreen, but it pays.

It's as they say, when the student is ready, the teacher arrives.

posts.com:
Your best bet is to work doing something you dont like for a while. Work overtime for a year in a farm and save up as much as you can, this means no buying toys, almost no clothes, no loans, no credit cards. You save up as much as you can and you can start investing that money, into learning a valuable skill, or buying something that will pay for itself. You can buy a lot of party equipment like bouncy castles, trampolines, vending machines, etc. and rent them out to parties. You could even buy a cab, fill it with a couple videogame consoles and rent them out to rich suburban kid parties for a good buck. Just because it seems small time or uninteresting doesnt mean theres not a chance to make money doing it.

To add to this plan I would recommend working your overtime job while renting what i said before, and youll invest some of your current savings into something that will not only pay for itself, but start paying YOU.
